remarks.format:
## Remarks The AddingNewEventArgs class provides data for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.BindingSource.AddingNew?displayProperty=fullName> event, which signals that an item is about to be added to a collection. The event gives the programmer, within the event handler <xref:System.ComponentModel.AddingNewEventHandler>, the option of supplying the new object by setting the <xref:System.ComponentModel.AddingNewEventArgs.NewObject%2A> property to this new item. If this property is not set, the collection will typically use the default constructor of the appropriate type to construct a new item. In either case, the new item will be added to the collection.
If the collection also implements the <xref:System.ComponentModel.ICancelAddNew> interface, the item will be provisionally added, waiting a subsequent commit or rollback.
This event is commonly used in data-binding scenarios, within classes such as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.BindingSource?displayProperty=fullName> and <xref:System.ComponentModel.BindingList%601?displayProperty=fullName>.
For more information about handling events, see [NIB: Consuming Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/01e4f1bc-e55e-413f-98c7-6588493e5f67).

remarks.format: ## Remarks The default constructor sets the <xref:System.ComponentModel.AddingNewEventArgs.NewObject%2A> property to `null`. A value that is `null` indicates that, if the <xref:System.ComponentModel.AddingNewEventHandler> does not explicitly set this property, the collection will take standard steps to provide a new item to add to itself.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The AddingNewEventArgs constructor sets the <xref:System.ComponentModel.AddingNewEventArgs.NewObject%2A> property to the `newObject` parameter. This object will be used as the new item to be added to the associated collection, unless this property is updated by the event handler.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If the NewObject property is set to `null`, it indicates that the collection is to take the standard action, which typically entails creating an object of the appropriate type using its default constructor, and then adding it to the collection.
